column2: San Ardo Elementary School\r--------\r62428 Center Street • San Ardo
column5: Principal\rcreimer@montereycoe.org\rhttps://sausd-k12-pt.schoolloop.com/\r\r2018-19 School Accountability Report Card\rPublished During the 2019-20 School Year\r\rSchool Description\r\rDistrict Mission Statement\rThe San Ardo Union Elementary School District is committed to providing the children of the\rcommunity with a high quality educational experience to prepare students for secondary school
column8: and beyond. The school district strives to provide a safe and healthy environment\rto aid all children in the learning process. The staff will maximize the students’ opportunities to\rincrease their knowledge
column11: and a sense of community responsibility.\r--------\rTheSanArdoUnionElementarySchoolDistrictisdedicatedtoprovidingstudentswiththe\rSan Ardo Union Elementary\rfoundation they need to reach their goals.\rSchool District\r\r62428 Center Street\rSan Ardo
column12: CA 93450Community & School Profile\r(831) 627-2520 Ext. 112The San Ardo Union Elementary School District is a single school district located in rural Monterey\rhttps://sausd-k12-County in the southern area of the Salinas Valley.  The district is approximately 19 miles south of\rpt.schoolloop.com/King City and 35 miles north of Paso Robles.  The school enrollment is approximately 114 students\r\rand attendance rates are fairly high (96%).  The district was established in 1900. The district\rDistrict Governing Board\roperatesonamodifiedyearroundscheduleserving114studentsingradestransitional\rKaeda Barrios
column13: President\rkindergarten through eighth grade.  Enrollment has been fairly consistent over the years fluctuating\r\rfrom a high of 125 students to a low of 100 students.  Three similar small school districts surround\rCindy Beal
column14: Clerk\rthe San Ardo District.\r\r\rEugene Duggins\rSan Ardo is an unincorporated area with 517 residents
column15: according to the 2010 Census count.  The\r\reconomy is based on farming
column18: and oil industry.  The majority of the residents work\rSalvador Macias\rin the agricultural business.  Although the economic status of the population varies widely
column19: 92% of\r\rthe students attending San Ardo School qualify for free and reduced meals through the National\rTiffini Moore\rSchool Lunch and Breakfast Program.  There is a mixture of single-family and multiple-family\r\rhomes.  Many parents are seasonal field workers.  Approximately 30% of parents have an education\rDistrict Administrationbeyond the equivalent of the 8th grade.   About 40% of parents speak little or no English
column21: Ed.D.though the majority of them have resided in the town for over 10 years.  San Ardo School has an\rSuperintendentEnglish Language Learner population currently of 89.5%.  The San Ardo School District had not\r\rredesignated students as Reclassified Fluent English Proficient (RFEP) for a period of seven years\rup until the 2014-15 academic year.  This has presented a difficulty in determining the accuracy of\rthe current population of English Language Learners.  In 2014-15
column22: (2) students were Redesignated\rFluent English Proficient (RFEP) and in 2015-16 (1) student was RFEP
column25: and in 2018-19 (4) students were RFEP.   San Ardo is not\ra migrant farming area
column26: as most families that move to the town tend to stay permanently.  There\rare no health or community services in the area.

column2: Average Class Size and Class Size Distribution (Elementary)\r2016-172016-172016-172016-172017-182017-182017-182017-182018-192018-192018-192018-19\rAverage# of# of# ofAverage# of# of# ofAverage# of# of# of\rGrade\rClassClasses*Classes*Classes*ClassClasses*Classes*Classes*ClassClasses*Classes*Classes*\rLevel\rSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSize\r1-2021-3233+1-2021-3233+1-2021-3233+\rK\r131141191\r\r2\r201241191\r\r4\r24121171\r\r6\r211221271\r\rOther**\r\r*Numbe r of classes indicates how many classes fall into each size category (a range of total students per class).\r** “Other” category is for multi-grade level classes.\r\r\rProfessional Development provided for Teachers\r\rMeasure2017-182018-192019-20\rNumber of school days dedicated to Staff Development and Continuous Improvement222\r\rThe primary areas of focus for professional development are English Language Arts and Mathematics.  It was determined that the school was lacking\rEnglish Language Arts and Mathematics curricular materials aligned with the Common Core State Standards.  Subsequently
column3: students were not\rperforming well on California Assessment of Student Performance and Progress.  The District has since adopted new programs aligned with the Common\rCore State Standards.  Teachers participated in training for the new English Language Arts curriculum with a larger District at the beginning of 2016-17.\rProfessional development has also included training from Project Lead the Way for implementation of the science materials.  Teachers have traveled to\rUniversities such in San Jose
column6: and Missouri to attend three to five day intensive training in 2016-17
column8: and 2019-20.  The\r2017-18 academic year included professional development from the Monterey County Office of Education on Navigating the Smarter Balanced\rAssessment Consortium (SBAC)
column9: the California Assessment of Student Performance and Progress (CAASPP)
column10: and setting SMART goals to increase student\rachievement.  In October of 2017
column11: we also began professional development in Guided Language Acquisition and Design (GLAD) strategies.  This\rprofessional development continued with in-class coaching and modeling through January and February 2018.  The District began the 2018-19 school\ryear with professional development on Step-up to Writing and school safety training.  The professional development continue through-out 2018-19 with\radditional days in January.  Teachers also conducted a review of the new social studies and history materials to implement a new program.  Several\rteachers and the administrator also attended a workshop in 2018-19 on performance-based assessment
column14: and creating performance tasks. The 2019-20 academic year began with professional development with the Monterey\rCounty Office of Education reviewing deepening math practices.  The professional development has continued with support providers from MCOE\robserving and supporting teachers in classrooms in mathematics and science.  Teachers also evaluate Next Generation Science Standards newly approved\rcurricula and made a recommendation for an adoption for 2020-21. The administrator attends all of the professional development and facilitates teacher-\rprincipal meetings to address issues with ongoing implementation.\r\rTeachers are paid for two additional days of professional development at the beginning of the school year.  The current administration has supported\rmany days beyond the two provided and will continue to support them.\rNew faculty members may also participate in the Teacher Induction program

It was determined that the school was lacking\rEnglish Language Arts and Mathematics curricular materials aligned with the Common Core State Standards.  Subsequently
column3: students were not\rperforming well on California Assessment of Student Performance and Progress.  The District has since adopted new programs aligned with the Common\rCore State Standards.
